page.title: 01 Introduction
page.content: A large amount of the land in this block has been reclaimed from the sea, and is now intensively farmed. Market gardening is the main activity. Hundred End Moss was originally a bog. In 1880 the Hesketh and Scarisbrick families built banks along the river,one from the South and one from the North,which ended at Hundred End Gutters. 100 years later,a local businessman,Mr.Godfrey Crook,built a bank 3/4 mile long to connect the previous two,and reclaimed 1100 acres of land. This reclamation has been closely followed by Dr.Johnson of Liverpool University,who was an advisor to Mr.Crook. This land is now classed as Grade 1 agricultural land, and there is less than 10 percent of all growing land under this classification.
